title: Implement Stack
description:
Implement Stack

Implement a stack data structure with the following operations:

  • push(val): Push an element onto the stack
  • pop(): Remove and return the top element from the stack
  • top(): Return the top element without removing it
  • empty(): Return whether the stack is empty

You can choose to implement the stack using either:

  1. Linked List - Each node points to the next node
  2. Circular Array - Fixed-size array with wrapping

Examples:

  • Input: ["Stack", "push", "push", "top", "pop", "empty"]
    [[], [1], [2], [], [], []]
    Output: [null, null, null, 2, 2, false]
  • Input: ["Stack", "push", "pop", "empty"]
    [[], [10], [], []]
    Output: [null, null, 10, true]

Constraints:

  • 1 <= val <= 10^9
  • At most 10^4 calls will be made to each function
  • pop and top will only be called on non-empty stacks
solution_text:
Implement Stack

Algorithm (Linked List Approach):

  1. Use a singly linked list where each node contains a value and pointer to next
  2. Maintain a head pointer to the top of the stack
  3. Push: Create new node and set as head
  4. Pop: Remove head and return its value
  5. Top: Return head value without removal
  6. Empty: Check if head is None

Algorithm (Array Approach):

  1. Use a Python list (dynamic array)
  2. Push: Append to end of list
  3. Pop: Remove and return last element
  4. Top: Return last element
  5. Empty: Check if list length is 0

Time Complexity: O(1) for all operations

Space Complexity: O(n) where n is number of elements

Key Insights:

  • Linked list uses more memory per element but no resizing overhead
  • Array uses less memory but may need to resize
  • Both approaches provide O(1) operations
  • Stack follows LIFO (Last In First Out) principle
